CListViewControl

A ListView control.  Additionally to its features present in AHK it can use sorting-independent indexing for synchronizing its fields with an array.

Summary
CListViewControlA ListView control.
Variables
ItemsContains all rows and fields.
SelectedItemContains the (first) selected row.
SelectedItemsContains all selected rows.
SelectedIndexContains the index of the (first) selected row.
SelectedIndicesContains all indices of the selected rows.

FocusedIndexContains the index of the focused row.
IndependentSortingThis setting is off by default.
Events
IntroductionTo handle control events you need to create a function with this naming scheme in your window class: ControlName_EventName(params) The parameters depend on the event and there may not be params at all in some cases.
Click(RowIndex)Invoked when the user clicked on the control.
DoubleClick(RowIndex)Invoked when the user double-clicked on the control.
RightClick(RowIndex)Invoked when the user right-clicked on the control.
DoubleRightClick(RowIndex)Invoked when the user double-right-clicked on the control.
ColumnClick(ColumnIndex)Invoked when the user clicked on a column header.
EditingStart(RowIndex)Invoked when the user started editing the first cell of a row.
EditingEnd(RowIndex)Invoked when the user finished editing a cell.
ItemActivate(RowIndex)Invoked when a row was activated.
KeyPress(KeyCode)Invoked when the user pressed a key while the control had focus.
MouseLeave()Invoked when the mouse leaves the control boundaries.
FocusReceived()Invoked when the control receives the focus.
FocusLost()Invoked when the control loses the focus.
Marquee()Invoked when the mouse gets moved over the control.
ScrollingStart()Invoked when the user starts scrolling the control.
ScrollingEnd()Invoked when the user ends scrolling the control.
ItemSelected(RowIndex)Invoked when the user selects an item.
ItemDeselected(RowIndex)Invoked when the user deselects an item.
SelectionChanged(RowIndex)Invoked when the selected item(s) has/have changed.
ItemFocused(RowIndex)Invoked when a row gets focused.
ItemDefocused(RowIndex)Invoked when a row loses the focus.
FocusedChanged(RowIndex)Invoked when the row focus has changed.
ItemChecked(RowIndex)Invoked when the user checks a row.
ItemUnchecked(RowIndex)Invoked when the user unchecks a row.
CheckedChanged(RowIndex)Invoked when the checked row(s) has/have changed.

Variables

Items

Contains all rows and fields.  Indexing and iterating over it is possible to retrieve a row.  A row has properties like Checked, Focused and Selected.  To access single cells it is possible to index or iterate over a row.  Icons can be assigned to rows by calling SetIcon(Filename, IconIndex) or by assigning an icon file to the Icon property of a row.

SelectedItem

Contains the (first) selected row.

SelectedItems

Contains all selected rows.

SelectedIndex

Contains the index of the (first) selected row.

SelectedIndices

Contains all indices of the selected rows.

CheckedItem

Contains the (first) checked row.

CheckedItems

Contains all checked rows.

CheckedIndex

Contains the index of the (first) checked row.

CheckedIndices

Contains all indices of the checked rows.

FocusedItem

Contains the focused row.

FocusedIndex

Contains the index of the focused row.

IndependentSorting

This setting is off by default.  In this case, indexing the rows behaves like AHK ListViews usually do.  If it is enabled however, the row indexing will be independent of the current sorting.  That means that the first row can actually be displayed as the second, third,... or last row on the GUI.  This feature is very useful if you need to synchronize an array with the data in the ListView because the index of the array can then be directly mapped to the ListView row index.  This would not be possible if this option was off and the ListView gets sorted differently.

Events

Introduction

To handle control events you need to create a function with this naming scheme in your window class: ControlName_EventName(params) The parameters depend on the event and there may not be params at all in some cases.  Additionally it is required to create a label with this naming scheme: GUIName_ControlName GUIName is the name of the window class that extends CGUI.  The label simply needs to call CGUI.HandleEvent().  For better readability labels may be chained since they all execute the same code.
